												OlliOlli is a skill and timing based 2D side scrolling runner with a skateboarding theme. I say runner, because even though you're riding a skateboard, you can't stop. You're always moving to the right. Its an original take on the genre and a fresh skateboarder. I'm not sure this game is for everyone because of the genre and control scheme.The goal is simple, make it to the end of each level without falling off your board. You'll grind, jump and ride your board to the end. Just you. Getting to the end unlocks the next level. Each career level has five optional goals. Things like get X score or X combo. Jump gaps, collect spray cans, do a kick flip, only use one push or grind everything that needs girding. When you accomplish all five goals in an amateur level, it unlocks a pro level. Not only do the goals keep you in the relatively short levels, but you're rewarded for playing completing them. Outside of the career half of the game there is a "spot" half, with 25 more armature levels. These spots require you to do one long trick combination to the end of the level. There are 25 pro spot levels to compliment the amateurs.The challenge isn't avoiding obstacles, its the unique control scheme. To get speed, you need to push with the simple tap of a button. Two taps gets you up to top speed. Now for the tricky part. Instead of having a jump button, you use the analog stick to hold in one direction to charge the jump and release. So you flick the stick to jump. The direction you flick the stick determines the trick in the jump. There is a trictionary if you're looking for a specific trip, but I don't think it matters what trick you do. Your momentum determines the distance of the jump. You can even do quarter circles, half circles and so on to perform bigger tricks. Its elegant and simple yet complex and difficult to time because of how unique it is. When you are about to land the jump, you need to hit the land button, which is the same as the push button. If you don't push the land button, you'll land a "sloppy" which briefly stuns your rider by making him unbalanced. Getting stunned makes you vulnerable to falling off your board because you can't jump. Hitting obstacles or falling down a flight of stairs sends your rider tumbling a comical distance. In a way its a funny bit to tell you that you've failed, but in another way its a time wasting punishment. There are several grades to your landing depending how close to the ground you hit the button. A sloppy landing can make 20 trick combination worthless for point value. The grade of your landing not only determines the score you get for the combination, but it changes your momentum. A sloppy landing slows you down while a perfect landing will make you speed up.Outside of pushes, jumps and landings, there are grinds and twists. Twisting in air requires you to hold the button before you jump so your rider gets into position. I didn't find these necessary, but if you want a bigger score, you'll twist like its the 1950s. Twists are true risks and rewards, because you can fail the level if you mess up. Grinds are much easier. If there's a wall, railing or rooftop, just push the analog stick and hold it. Releasing it makes the rider jump as he normally would. Getting big combos relies on your ability to grind. Like with landings, you can score perfect grinds too, depending on how late you time your grind. Some of the later levels rely on your ability to make perfect grinds, because they keep your momentum going. Just know this is what you're getting yourself into.There is an easy to use, optional tutorial that explains all the controls. Everything gets explained one by one before the game makes you do them.There are five themes in OlliOlli each has its own color pallet. A grey urban, a brown pallet junkyard, a blue port, a snowy white base reminiscent of Rush'n Attack and finally the bright neon city. They are all beautiful, but they go by in an unnoticeable blur. I couldn't pay attention to anything other than was there a grind or a landing coming? As the levels get higher, the challenge grows. The base has safe pavement to land on, but a lot of it is snow that sends you tumbling. Its fun to grind over helicopter blades and statues instead of simple railings and walls. Neon city is mostly rooftops and railings to grind on, because the ground is either pink spikes or wide stairways.To keep you in the game there are daily challenges that let you practice as much as you want, but you only have one real attempt. Each level has its own leader boards after every attempt.  The game keeps track of your high score of each level and your best trick combination for that run. Truth be told, the game did freeze and twice crash in four hours after some completed runs. I assume because it was loading leader board standings and couldn't.The soundtrack is also a real standout. The lo fi electronic beats fit the art style. For the most part it felt like all mellow songs, but there is an eclectic mix of tunes. No matter what the beat, nothing got in the way and just added to the feeling of zoning out that I had while playing. The game became all timing with no thought. I just knew from playing that was the millisecond I needed to do something. After spending 20 - 30 minutes on some of the later levels of the amateur career, I could might be able to do them blindfolded.In the future I'd like to see different riders to unlock. Not that the rider was anything bad, but it was just him for the 4 hours I played. I am thankful for him having a red hat, otherwise he may have gotten lost in the blur of the background.In conclusion, its a fantastic presentation and a test of skill, but I'm not sure how fun the game actually is. I found my mind not as engaged as my reflexes were. I wasn't having any joy going through the motions. Although I did get a few laughs seeing my rider tumble down flights of staircases and seeing just how many meters he could go. Its still a good game, but after going through the armature career and spots, I'm just not that willing to unlock all the pro levels.

												Let's go in steps here.First of all, you probably need a controller to enjoy this game, even the game tells you that when you're opening it without your controller plugged in. I haven't tried playing with my keyboard, but with the controller you use your analog stick to do tricks, so it involves a lot of spinning it around in multiple ways and pressing buttons along to do all the complex stunts you need without really having to think too much about it. Simple to learn, challenging (in a fun way!) to master, as it offers a fulfilling variety of stunts of different levels that you can perform. Is this another one of those endless running / distance games?It involves distance, but it isn't endless. The game is comprised of "stages" with a number of goals you can accomplish in each of those. Each stage has a certain distance, to go to the next one, usually all you need to do is finish the stage in one piece. However, you also have the option of completing one or more of those multiple goals that each stage offers. Completing all goals in a level unlocks a new difficulty of that level, with even more challenges. So it's a bit different of the boring endless distance games that have been crowding the game market lately.Is there a story?Sorry, not really, but even though I love games with stories, I didn't miss in this case because the game mechanics keep you hooked init. It's actually very easy to completely forget about your goals even, just because you got so excited that you got like 10 perfects in a row and you want to see how far you can go.What else can you say about this game?As you're playing, you learn with your mistakes, so even when you fail it doesn't get frustrating, because you get that feeling that in just a few more tries you'll get it right. Some times you'll have to stop doing the stunts you tend to overuse, and pull different strategies and combos to get the objects in the field that you need to collect to complete a challenge. There's also a big variety of stunts you can perform, as well as the techniques you need to develop to get perfect landings, nosegrinds, to get better speed without having to put your foot on the ground to push your skate faster, etc.Yeah, it's a casual game, but I tell you, it's addictive. (I just spent 2 hours playing it nonstop, and had to stop myself because I had work to do, otherwise I would've kept going - even just writing this review makes me want to go back and play it a bit more!) My only sadness so far? I wish it had more steam achievs, I feel like this game has a lot of cool achievement possibilities, but sadly that wasn't well explored. At least we get cool in-game coals to achieve, though!

												OlliOlli strips trick-based skateboarding down to its most exhilarating, addicting elements.It’s the practice and lead up to a perfect run; the repeated failure and experimentation over and over until finally you nail that perfect combo and the multipliers go crazy. OlliOlli takes that key moment and feeling that was pioneered, refined, and then beaten into the ground by Tony Hawk Pro-Skater, and removes all the fluff and needless bloat that began to weigh the series down the further it went on.Some of this is accomplished inherently by moving from a 3D sandbox to an always moving sidescroller, which immediately gives OlliOlli a great deal of originality. But developer Roll7 clearly knows and loves the games that built (and subsequently largely destroyed) the extreme sports genre, and borrows liberally the pieces that worked best from them to make a new, disturbingly addictive blend of mechanics.It’s Tony Hawk’s eccentricity, Skate’s organic trick system, and a whole lot of intelligent endless runner progression design. Performing tricks is as simple as flicking the analogue stick, but having to time your landings adds a considerable amount of risk versus reward to performing longer tricks when your movement speed is largely out of your control and it’s not always easy to predict what’s going to meet you later on in the level.OlliOlli can be absurdly difficult at parts, but it’s a challenge that I always felt prepared for. The goals for each level gradually introduce new moves into your skillset, and then gave me the perfect area to learn them. There’s a feeling of constant growth as you clear each level and the gradually climbs to counteract it, but also an understanding that for some players certain challenges will be out of their reach. OlliOlli never forced me to clear a goal or spend more time on a certain level than I wanted to, but it was so successful at instilling confidence in my ability to overcome whatever it threw at me that I rarely had any desire to move on before showing the game how capable I was.I did eventually abandon some levels, surrendering that I wasn’t quite as skilled as I pretended to be, but unlike a lot of games my experience wasn’t tarnished in any way for doing so. OlliOlli seems designed from the ground up to be as much as you want to put into it, and providing an awesome time whatever that is. The short levels are perfect for picking off in small bursts, and the addition of a daily grind which changes daily and gives a you only one chance to hit your best score, gave even more reason to return to the game instead of trying to plow through it all at once.My biggest frustration with OlliOlli actually doesn’t have anything to do with what’s here, but the disappointing absence of a convenient leaderboard. You can track your score and compare it with others in any level you choose, but instead of being prominently displayed it’s put on a separate screen completely removed from gameplay. For a game so perfectly designed for chasing high scores (you even unlock score focused “spots” after clearing each level once), having something like Geometry Wars 2’s immediate tracking of leaderboard positioning and your next score to beat would have been far more compelling a motivator for me to chase my friend’s best scores.That may matter more or not at all depending on your feelings toward competing on leaderboards, but it’s at least telling that my only major issue with OlliOlli is in something it lacks (and even then, it’s more the implementation than complete absence of a feature). It’s a game so precisely tuned and refined that I found myself becoming lost for hours at a time repeating levels attempting to best my prior run. It gave me a sense of accomplishment and elation at expertly executing a sequence of tricks I haven’t felt in a decade, and reminded me why I’m so sad games of this nature were killed off by their own insistence on flooding the market and deluding themselves with features nobody wanted. OlliOlli suffers from none of that. It’s pure, sublime skating perfection.On the PC version:While the PC version of OlliOlli is content complete to its Playstation 4 and Vita counterparts, the port has sadly suffered a great deal in the transition. I experience a significant amount of technical issues, from dropped frames, persistent slowdown, leaderboards crashing the game, and a generally lower level of responsiveness than a game so reliant on timing needs. It wasn’t so bad I was unable to enjoy the game or play it successfully, but if you have the ability to play it on another platform it might be advisable to do so.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

												Absolutely excellent little game.One of the most common things you'll read about it elsewhere on the internet is that it's really hard. This is true-- but OlliOlli's difficulty is fair, fun, and rewarding. Landing tricks is legitimately difficult and feels great. After a few play sessions, you should really start to feel yourself improving.The controls are extremely simple-- left analog stick to line up a trick, 'A' button to push against the ground or land the end of a trick combo. Tricks are controlled by the directions you push the left analog stick. Releasing the stick causes your character to jump in the air and attempt the trick. Sweeping the stick around in a circle will line up a more complicated trick, based on the distance and direction you sweeped it. The only way to get credit for a trick or a combo is to tap the 'A'button quickly just before you hit the ground. The closer to the ground, the better multiplier you get.Overall, the system is simple and rewards practice. Chaining together a long combo is quite difficult, and you'll have to chain some pretty ridiculous ones to complete all the objectives in each campaign level.Speaking of levels-- the "Career" campaign has several "acts" with eight tracks each-- four easy, four hard. Each act has its own art style. There's also a "Spots" mode, where you get to execute precisely one combo before the level ends. Extending that combo gets you more points and a better spot on the leaderboards. The final game mode is the "Daily Grind." It provides a single randomly-generated track that you only get one chance to set a score on. So far, the Daily Grind I've tried has been quite hard.I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys twitchy, timing-based platformers or arcadey, combo-centric skill games. Not for the weak of heart, but ultimately accessible to anyone with a gamepad and the will to improve.It's also worth mentioning that the soundtrack is excellent.

												I find the prospect of having to ride on a board with wheels under it a very, very terrifying experience. There are many ways I can fall off that board, and I imagine all of them have to do with something like falling onto a turd or a water hydrant or onto a set of figurines that are participating in a heated battle of Warhammer 40,000 on the sidewalk, where I will pierce one of my internal organs on a Tyranid and have to explain to God when I get to the pearly gates why I am such an ultra-wuss.OlliOlli captures some of that terror because it has a difficulty curve that's steep as hell, like learning how to ride an actual skateboard. The tutorial could have been better (for some reason I couldn't actually figure out how to do Perfect Grinds until I just said '♥♥♥♥ this' and played an actual level, where I slowly figured it out on my own, but I think that's more of my blatant inattentiveness than the tutorial's fault), but the real learning experience is pretty much about getting better and faster at the game, and learning how to squeeze in more tricks between grinds for higher scores or for unlocking bigger, better levels. If you want to unlock those "Pro" levels, you gotta ♥♥♥♥ing earn your keep. Once you get in the groove of actually starting to pull off sweet moves and getting in the habit of varying what moves you pull off, the game opens up dramatically and challenges you even more.Despite OlliOlli's semi-'thrown in the deep end' type of tutorial, it gets its vibe right. The soundtrack is the perfect thing to grind to, and the controls are a bit finicky but the way they are built allows for effortless cool stunts between jumps. It looks cool and I bet you will not be called a nerd if you show people how you can do a 1080 Backside Flip-It to people on the bus without losing. It's Super Meat Boy hard - you will break your knees and ankles so many times before you can finally pull off that grind-flip-grind-twist-grind-perfect landing combo, and it will feel glorious. If you can beat all the Rad levels, I bet you can show someone at the interview for your next job and you will get that job.Personally (oh no! Personally, the verboten word in video game reviews), I'm not a fan of these endless hardcore trek-up-Death-Mountain challenges, and OlliOlli didn't change my mind. But I like what it's doing enough to recommend it.

												OlliOlli is a 2d skateboarding game that bares similarities to the gameplay of now defunct developer Black Box skateboarding game "Skate". The basic control scheme is all there, you have your left analog stick quarter circles, full circles and point analog at said direction to pull off a variety of combo skateboarding tricks and grinds. Sure it doesn't have any of the crazy stunts of a Tony Hawk like 720 shove it-to -superman-heelflip-whatever but pulling off chain combo in OlliOlli has just the degree of difficult and requires just the amount of skill that pulling them off will give players an equal amount of gratification when done properly. Players progress in challenge latened levels where either collecting, pulling off x amount of combos, or reaching a certain amount of score will progress you to the next level and ultimately to more difficult challenges. When it comes to presentation OlliOlli 2d pixelated art style helps sets it apart from the more well known 3D skateboarding franchises by giving the game a indie feel very reminiscent of underground skateboarding back in the day. This feeling is reinforced by the music that not only helps set the tone but remind players the variety and diversity skateboarding is. There's a level of cool brought to this game simply by choosing these aesthetics. A few issues I had with this game was primarily on the mechanics side where the initial timing for the landing of tricks require players to press a button at the right time to pull it off perfectly. This window to press the button is fairly short and requires you to pay attention to how far your board is to the ground. This can prove an issue because like other 2d endless runners before it if you aren't paying attention to the screen correctly your character may blend into the background which can prove troublesome.  Failing to pull off the perfect landing on a trick can be the difference between getting 100k score on a perfectly run level to 20k score on a poorly runned one. Overall if you ever had an interest in skateboarding games or were interested in this game when it initally came out on Playstation Vita but didn't have the hardware to play it, I think this is a game worth picking up.

												To hear to more of my thoughts on OlliOlli, listen to the episode on Game Hoard Podcast[gamehoardpodcast.com]GameplayIn OlliOlli your primary goal is simply to ride your skateboard to the end of each obstacle-filled level without crashing. Crash and you have to restart the level. Essentially the game plays like a runner-style game with your character constantly moving forward, although the high level of precision needed for the later levels almost makes it feel like a rhythm game. Secondary to beating each level, you can focus on getting high scores and beating challenges for each level, such as scoring a certain combo or getting all the collectibles.OlliOlli has a simple but unique control scheme where you perform tricks by holding and releasing the left control stick and pressing A to speed up and stick landings while your character continually moves forward. It definitely took me some time to get used to the fact that pressing A does not make jump while wiggling the control stick does but, once I got a hang of it, I found that this type of control offers up a lot of freedom and works quite well.Overall, I enjoyed OlliOlli's gameplay a lot. It's a fast-paced steep challenge that I enjoyed as a fan of precision platformingArt DirectionWhile I enjoyed the distinctness of OlliOlli's five worlds, Urban, Junkyard, Port, Base (soviet Russia), and Neon (retro-future Tokyo), and the crisp clean menus, I found the simple pixel graphics of OlliOlli during actual gameplay to be somewhat lackluster. They aren't bad but they also didn't stick with me and it was occasionally hard to distinguish what was purely an obstacle and what I may be able to grind, which was problematic.Sound DesignOlliOlli is yet another indie title with a fantastic soundtrack. The music seems to take influence from a number of sources and has elements of electronic, jazz, and hip-hop. It's upbeat, catchy, and kept me going as I crashed over and over again.The sound effects are fine but much less memorable.OverviewOlliOlli is a fun runner-style sidescrolling game with a steep challenge that features a unique control scheme and a great soundtrack. You don't need to care for real life skateboarding at all to enjoy this one. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a high precision sidescroller to test their skills.

												Reminiscing the age of Tony Hawk's Pro skater, OlliOlli is an objective based skateboarding game that re-imagines the 3D formulae into a retro 2D side-scroller. Originally developed for the PS Vita by Roll7 – the windows port up-scales the game whilst offering a similar experience. But does it grind past its contemporaries or face-plant into failure?   The games primary feature is a single player career mode. This is split across 5 distinct areas each divided into 5 courses. Your tasked with completing each course to unlock the next with increasing difficulty as you progress. There are also a list of 5 objectives within each course, and if completed you unlock a 'Pro' variation of the same course. Each run is fairly short and can be successfully completed within a few minutes. To supplement this once you've unlocked a course, they can then be revisited as skating 'spots', allowing you to compete on a score board, ranking players across the globe. The final mode is a challenge variant called 'Daily Grind' which challenges the player to grind the entirety of a run. You can practice as many times as you want but you can only compete once. Your score is also ranked, however this resets with a new course every day. Although OlliOlli is a fairly compact game – the polish and refinement to the gameplay and mechanics makes it easy to jump in and out of. Its highly satisfying to pull off a series of tricks and slide down a rail to 100% a course, and although it can be frustrating when your stuck on a run at times, its easy to step away for a few hours and pick up where you left off later. There is also the option to skip through the levels.The gradual increase in difficulty is the perfect means to encourage players to perfect their timing. It also encourages the revisit of past levels, as new skills are picked up that will allow previously impossible objectives to be overcome. The game can feel intimidating at first but through familiarising yourself with the tutorials and the 'tricktionary' the player can steadily progresses through the game – never becoming too hard or too easy.Although the game is primarily single player there is a thrill with trying to out-do players on the scoreboards, and its easy to go back to a run that you've had much success and find you've been out done. The daily grind is also another great incentive to try boast you timing and trick combinations. The games biggest weakness is perhaps its controls, as a handheld port – the instant response of controller buttons is required. A keyboard can hinder the players timing and weakens the core mechanics of the game. There were also occasions where the keys would not register a move resulting in a sloppy landing or bail. However a controller solved all these problems. On the rare occasion the game suffered from glitches that allowed us to grind through obstacles or bail on a perfect landing. Although there isn't anything particularly impressive about the aesthetics of the game the art style is very charming. Particularly the animated background environments, and the skater himself, who has unique animations for each trick which can be viewed within the 'tricktionary'. However the contrast between the slow background and fast character can sometimes be disorientating, drawing focus away from the speed of the foreground.OlliOlli has a subtle electronic score which really suits the retro feel of the game. Although you hear the same tracks multiple times, they can come in at just the right moment to spur you on to victory. The game manages to avoid feeling repetitive through remaining a challenge. Rather than testing the patient of the player, there is the ability to restart at any point in a run and progressively improve over an individual course. OlliOlli is a great example of when less is more,  but with a sequel announced for next year promising to expand on its successes, we can't wait to get back on ours board.Video Review at:

												Leave it to Devolver to take another great, simple concept, with run-away potential and screw it up. The controls in this game are so stupidly done it almost seems as if they made a bet with the staff to see who could create the most counter-intuitive operations possible for a fast-paced action/sports game. Last Devolver game I buy. After Hotline Miami I said the same thing and I honestly didnt even see that this was Devolver when I bought it on sale. When I saw the logo pop up when I started the game I said "&$#@, cant believe I missed that". Since they wanted to rely so heavily on the analog sticks (which I totally approve) they shouldve never made a requirement of using "A" to land every single trick. Since "A" is also used to pump for speed it should only be used for transitioning between rails...if even that. Setting up for tricks and activating them didnt need to be dependant on 1/4, 1/2, 3/4, etc rotations and then releasing when using the D-pad is much more precise and you can get a longer trick list if you incorporate the diagonals as a defined direction.Thyeve made blasting out tricks between grinds unecessarily difficult...even on the first levels. The tutorial will tell you to grind everything because that wil give you more speed. Except for when it doesnt and it stops you dead, causes you to fall, and you have to restart your run. Dumb dumb dumb dumb dumbAnyway, trick execution is abnormally stupid. And I know how this happens. One person came up with the control scheme. It felt natural to them and they implemented it (this is someone who was just mediocre at the original Tony Hawk games and was mad that their friends were able to score higher than them). The rest of the staff thought that since the game itself wouldnt really be challenging or fun, they could just roll with the control scheme being counter-intuitive and that would suffice for a game that was well thought out. Using "A" to land is so wildly stupid that I cant even fathom how that stayed in for the final version. First of all, landing your tricks in real life is totally dependant on your prior execution. They couldve easily done one of two things to incorprate a skill/timing based landing function. Either use "down" on the analog stick or make your landing dependant on your execution. Too little speed and you may land wobbly, too much and you may not be able to set up for the next execution. Their levels are laid out perfectly for the latter.Its amazing how well Devolver is getting at taking something that is different, fresh, and has tons of potential and just smashing it into pieces and then taking a hot steaming dump right on top of it. Thank god I only paid $6 for this. Uninstalled!If anyone is hell bent on getting this game please respond here first and I'll put up even more reasons why you should save your money. 												Glad I got this as part of a bundle and didn't pay for it on its own.If you're like me, the controls will infuriate you.  The fun you derive from this game is by creating a smooth flow throughout a level. Obstacles and incorrect timing are what interrupt the flow in a 3d game. In a 2D game, you'll find it's more often the confusing controls and what you can't see emerging from the right side of the screen that will interrupt your flow, and thus, your fun.The primary problem is that it has a very strange control layout that doesn't quite translate from Tony Hawk's 3D world well enough to a 2D world. I wish jumping was just bound to a single button, instead of having you pull back on the left stick of the controller to "charge" a jump (which is more time consuming - which, in a reaction based game like this, can be killer). And while pressing a button to stick a landing is all well and good, it's extremely hard to time it well enough to get a smooth flow going.  It's almost like they ripped touch controls from a mobile game, and tried to emulate them on a gamepad.And this is the problem, really: Is this game a complicated endless runner, or is it a watered-down skating game? It doesn't quite know, and it simultaneously fails at both.I've spent about 15 minutes on this title, and I can't honestly see myself being bothered to try and master it, which is a shame because I like the music and aesthetic.How this game because an indie darling, I'll never know. And I generally like what Devolver publishes.

												OlliOlli is a good example of a clever game idea executed poorly. The concept is simple: you control a skateboarder through various 2d levels and perform tricks based off of jumps and rails, racking up points through carefully executed combos and landings. The controls are fairly straightforward and the levels aren’t too hard to pick up….at least until later on when the difficulty curve goes through a sudden spike.In the last two areas of the game the developers seemed to want to punish the player as much as possible by requiring absolute perfection on every single jump and grind. This would be alright by me except the timing for a perfect landing or grind seems to differentiate between parts of a level and hitting the directional or landing button before contact at a certain pixel distance will net a different result when it should be exactly the same every time. This made the second level of the final area absolutely impossible for me and earlier parts extremely difficult to pass. It doesn’t help that for the hard levels, the developers thought putting the most brutal part near the beginning was a good idea. Forcing the player to die over and over again before they even make it 10 seconds into the level is really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ IMO and just results in a lot of frustration for when you finally get past it and then die another few seconds later, only to return to struggling with that first 10 seconds. Finally, I had stability issues with the game whenever my connection to steam servers wasn’t so good and it would crash to desktop several times. I won’t be getting the sequel to this one unless the engine and level design get a serious overhaul.

												Note : I do not recommend this game for most people, but i do recommend it if you're a perfectionist, who like to replay the same level over and over again until it's perfect. Read below for more explanation.OlliOlli frustrates me greatly. I was expecting a fun skateboard game where i could mess around a bit and do some crazy tricks. And though OlliOlli is all about unreal tricks that make you fly high into the air, it is not designed for casual fun. OlliOlli is a game for perfectionists only.The game requires you to always perform flawlessly. If you mess up a trick, then there is a high chance you will crash, which ends the level immediately. So there is no casual fun in OlliOlli, because you have to know the levels by heart, and constantly chain tricks correctly to avoid crashing.This merciless system is compounded by an unusual control scheme. The majority of skateboard/snowboard games have a jump button, and simply ask you to have a stabilize your board before landing. OlliOlli does the opposite : there is no dedicated jump button, but there is a landing button. It takes a while to get used to press a button to land. Moreover, the timing is very strict, so if you mess it up you're gonna be screwed right away. If you fail a landing, 2 things may happen : best case scenario, your combo score is cut severely, to the point that the 10x or 50x combo you got is useless, and your speed is cut down. Worst case scenario, your skater loses his balance, and doesn't get back in time to avoid the next obstacle: instant crash, level is over.So, the game is really unforgiving. But it also doesn't help players to learn how to play correctly, the game does a poor job at explaining itself. Though a tutorial will guide through the basics, the game doesnt tell you how it scores combo. For example it doesnt tell you whether it's important to get different tricks in the same combo, whether it's important to get a long grind or just hitting the grind and jumping again is enough, etc. All this means you're gonna have to figure out by trial and error if you want to achieve a score objectives or get a highscore on the leaderboards.In the end, everything in OlliOlli is meant for people that enjoy doing things over and over again until they perform it perfectly well and reach the highest scores. I'm not one of theses people, and hence i get frustrated by the game. If you're one of these people, I think you will enjoy the game. Otherwise, stay clear of it.One redeeming feature of the game for me : the sound design and the soundtrack, both of these are excellent and i enjoy them very much.

												OlliOlli is a simple, but fun, challenging, and mildly addictive skateboarding game. It's an arcade-styled game that focuses on stringing together combos of skateboard tricks to grab the high score, and knockout different objectives. Levels become progressively more challenging, as do the objectives. There are several game modes including a "Daily Grind" to compete for global high scores each day, and multiple versions of each level that can be unlocked by completing all that levels objectives. There's no lack of content, for sure. The game play is entertaining and challenging - landing a long combo of crazy tricks perfectly is so satisfying, and ♥♥♥♥ing up can be terribly frustrating. Personally, I find the frustration and fun to be equally balanced in a way that makes the game addicting, but in short bursts. It's the kind of game I play for half an hour at a time because of a spontaneous desire to beat a high score or try one of the Daily Grinds. The only two negatives I can come up with are the keyboard controls are a kinda wonky (although the game clearly states it was designed for controller play) and the price tag is a little steep. But overall, I'd recommend OlliOlli.

If you get easily frustrated from dying and restarting, then this game won't appeal to you.I love the music in this game, it's a great little sound track. Speaking of landing buttons, herein lies one of my most frustrating problems with this game: the controls. When trick modifier and spin are the same button and I want to jump > spin > land with a modified grinding trick, all that happens is I keep spinning because I didn't leave enough of a pause between letting go and pressing the button. Next, if you want to jump, you have to press the trick input. It works but it would have felt better if there was a separate button for jumping, tricks and landing. Lastly, I wanted to mention the level design. While the levels made good obstacle courses, I found it difficult to keep track of my skater on the final stage as a lot of the colours blur in together. I also had a problem with the Junkyard stage as most things were brown and all too often I wouldn't see an obstacle before it was too late.All in all, I did have fun with this game but with a mixture of problems between controls and frustrating level design, I'll be designating this game to the bottom of my pile of games that I won't be playing again. A relatively arcadey 2D sidescrolling skateboard game where each level doesn't stop until you wipeout or get to the end.It's essentially all about trying to complete various challenges in each level while also trying to dish out the highest score doing various tricks & grinds before you reach the end mark or eat pavement. Many of the challenges require multiple runs of the same level and the more challenging ones may become a marathon of trial & errors mainly because the map will likely have to be memorized to an extent so as not to miss certain rails to grind on or gaps to jump and such. Each level has 5 challenges each and as soon as you finish one then that one challenge is completed for the rest of the game. To get the highest scores you have to combo up grinds & tricks as much as you can before landing back on the ground. While all levels are relatively short most have an absurdly extensive amount of rails and other objects for you to grind on to keep combos going. Some levels allow going from start to finish without even hitting the pavement until the very end which can be a pretty cool challenge of its own. There are no checkpoints but because the game's made for trial & error restarting a level after failure goes by pretty fast.The game is designed to be played with a controller in mind and although playing with the keyboard is allowed it's unrecommended. The game is played out using only the joystick (WASD) for performing tricks & ollies and the shoulder buttons (left & right arrow keys) for performing spins midair or doing other various tricks & grinds when combined with joystick moves.Whatever combo that's been made aren't fully counted for unless a PERFECT landing to the ground has been made which can be done by pressing A (down key) just right before making contact with the ground. Grinds can be landed at a PERFECT as well though the penalty is much more minimal if not timed well enough as opposed to missing landings on the ground.The skater moves on his own so you're really only in control of his score spewing moves and speed while at the same time avoiding wipeouts. Trying to perform various tricks & grinds felt a bit complicated early on, even after the tutorial, but I found myself getting a better feel for it as I kept playing especially when some challenges want you to perform specific tricks which usually become much more simpler than they sound. The number of tricks themselves feel very limited despite it saying "over 120" and they consist of board flips, spins, grinds, and ollies. Some of the animations for the tricks take a bit of time before being completed so learning what to use and when can also be a big deal when trying to stay on the board or not miss a rail to grind on just because your trick took too long. On that note you can actually finish most of the challenges with just ollies since they have practically no animation to wait for.Personally I disliked whatever kind of music was in here. Luckily I'm able to turn that off and pump up my own tracklist on another window of the THPS series OST and whatever other genres I felt more appropriate for skating.The game presents itself with a handful of glitches that can be incredibly infuriating to those looking to do outstanding to perfect runs. One of those would be that when you try to connect a grind you'll sometimes fall under the rail or just wipeout completely, even midway through the grind. The only time you're supposed to wipeout during grinding in this game is when you get off and land on something that isn't pavement, land on stairs, or hit an obstacle at the end of the rail which are never present between the beginning and the end of any rail.It could just be on my end but the controls become unresponsive often when performing fast actions. Uncommonly when I try to jump an ollie or a trick from the ground with the joystick nothing will happen which usually leads to a wipeout. There are also times when trying to do an ollie or trick I just suddenly wipeout on the long flat road I'm riding on as if the character slipped without even getting any airtime. The "slipping" doesn't really show that it's a part of the game so I'm lead to assume it's another glitch.This was apparently ported from another console and it's not entirely well polished either; the game crashes rarely for whatever reason, sometimes I have no control over the menus thus forcing me to restart the game, and there are rare & random but minute frame drops & skips which can be gamebreaking for a game that requires precise timing.There's not a whole lot to the game as each level & somewhat spread out challenges are actually just more of the same with a different setting however because I can be a sucker for skateboard games I had my big share of enjoyment from it. It's somewhat lacking so I probably wouldn't get this for 13 bucks.

												I love the idea, and as someone who was pretty damn good at chaining together combos of grinds w/ manuals for tons of points in tony hawk games, I was excited about this game. Sadly it is very rough around the edges. Let’s first talk about some of the worst controls I’ve ever seen. To jump you hold down, and to do tricks you hold down and make arc motions on the analog stick. Yes, you actually CAN’T use a/x to jump, the uniform jumping game button. You don’t even press up on analog like most games, you press DOWN! Then if you want to land a trick you have to press JUMP (durr duurrr), but if you want to land on rails with grinds, you use down for that. See how confusing and pointlessly dumb it is. You also can’t rebind the controls to A to jump as I tried. So good luck dying 200 times because you press A to jump or press down on analog to land, unlearning everything you have from gaming the past how-ever many years, just so this game can have “a steep learning curve”. If the controls don’t hurt the fun, there’s the game mechanics. Tons of times when I would press A at the exact right time it would say I completely missed it and will screw up the trick, and because that makes you unable to do anything for 5 seconds I would inevitable fall down and die. Other times I would press it when I did before and it would say perfect/sick, showing how inconsistent the landing feature feels. Then there is grinding. Countless times I would press the grind button above a rail only to fall past it without grinding and lose. Also the items being in the background means you will hit things you didn’t know were part of the course. Also I had bugs where I would just suddenly fall while grinding as if I got hit, but I hadn’t. Another time it said I was grinding but also made the sound counting me as falling, so I ended up grinding for 3 seconds before the game decided I had fallen. Also there will be times where you don’t know what’s coming up and you jump and land and there isn’t enough room to land and then jump again, meaning you must lose once more because you couldn’t see what was ahead and it was out of your control and already decided, which is dumb. Then there is the camera. For some inexplicable reason, the camera is towards the top of the screen. I would constantly be falling and not able to see the ground, to see if there is steps, a rail, or ground. Also in levels with snow where the sidewalk is missing, it will count as hitting you while you are still on the walkway, which makes no sense. Snow in place of a sidewalk is lower and basic physics means that shouldn’t hit you before you get there. Also the game won’t register jumps sometimes when you press them. Same goes for tricks like 60% of the time. 												Olli Olli is a loveletter to things like the original generation playstation 1 skateboarding games. You remember everything you loved about Tony Hawks Pro Skater on the playstation 1? What Thrasher: Skate and Destroy made you feel as you aced trick after trick in a huge combo?Well it's not quite on the par with those games, obviously, because they are 3d and kinda open world... but in a way, this is something of a purer experience. OlliOlli is two dimentional, and ... well basically combine Canabalt with THPS and you pretty much have what the game is gameplay wise. You are always moving forwards, you can't go back and redo a trick without restarting entirely. The course is always to the right and there's no going back.Because it's a "simpler" control system, where your left stick controls what trick you're doing and timing that landing button (A on your controller) perfectly is key to getting huge combos, you will quickly find yourself struggling a little. It's a hard game to control! Especially when grinds come into the mixture because it seems the devs, to increase challenge and keep you on your toes, deliberately made sure that landing a grind perfectly means using the Left Stick instead of the A button. Honestly though, I don't mind. The cognitive dissonance it causes is a little frustrating, but it's possible to overcome it.Graphics wise, it's full of wonderful, colourful pixels. I'm pretty early on into the game so the game isn't hugely detailed yet, the trailer seems to imply that later levels will be bigger, grander, more complex and more exciting though, which is nice. It's not hugely graphically intensive, so the game runs at a fantastic speed regardless of your rig, so it's got that going for it, but the pixel style really isn't going to be for everyone. Pixelly graphics is something that appeals to a particular niche... granted a fairly LARGE niche but still a niche none the less. I am part of said niche but I recognise the validity of the opinions of people who prefer more graphical fidelity than chunky low-res sprites. That's fair. Not everything needs to be pixel graphics, or low-poly chunky-ness, or mired in nostalgia.Music? Incredible. I love it. A fantasic mix of techno-hiphop-trance and a bunch of other electronic styles. It's very listenable and very very good to get you in the mood for the game. It mixes perfectly. My only gripe is that I can't get the soundtrack as one package, which is a terrible shame but understandable because, just like the old THPS games, the soundtrack is a collection of various tracks from various artists, each of which were released not specifically for this game, but as part of said artists' own albums and record labels. So yeah. Gotta go get the tracks individually. THANKFULLY the devs put in a tracklist in the credits, which is nice!The price of this game is £9.99 or regional equivalent, and I think personally that it's very reasonably priced. A lot of work has gone into making this game playable and fun, and not overly frustrating, the soundtrack's great, the mechanics are rock solid, so yes, £9.99 is a great price for this game and well worth it. You'll get well over 10 hours of gameplay from this and will most likely keep coming back to it, so that's totally worth the price.Okay so, in summary, here's the good and bad parts of this little gem:GOOD:Solid, engaging and fun mechanicsGreat soundtrackVery well tuned twitch gameplayVery reasonable priceBAD:Missing manuals! But that's coming in the sequelGraphical style MAY NOT appeal to everyone (again though the sequel is not pixelly by the looks of things!)Challlenging control system may frustrate people to begin with.For those wanting the complexity and depth of THPS, this game may well disappoint. Overall rating:A good solid 8/10I'm not a huge fan of skating games but this is great fun and a joy to play. Totally worth the money!

Unlike THPS, you don't have separate buttons for jumping, tricks and grinding, and you have to press down every time you land, or you'll fall.The game is playable with a keyboard, but it's much better with a controller.
